channel.title: Riddles/Conundrums?
channel.description:
Anyone have any riddles or conundrums to share? I love them, especially when they're based on math. :)
If you do in fact have some to share, post the riddle or conundrum and post the answer in very small font so we can't "cheat" haha.

item.title: Riddles/Conundrums?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:16, topic:428706”]Difference between 44 and 48 is 4

Difference between 40 and 44 is also 4

Same with 10-4=6 and 16-10=6[/quote]
didn’t read the rules lol

@Taharok: I guess you’re correct, was an easy riddle nonetheless.

Bump.

Read full topic

item.title: Riddles/Conundrums?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:15, topic:428706”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=531397.msg3883271#msg3883271 date=1326228314]

I posted this in the other thread for you, but I’ll post it here also:
Every week you play the lottery and you always play the same number. To play you pick six integers between 1 and 49, inclusive.

The numbers you pick have these properties:

The difference between any two of the six numbers is different from the difference between any other pair.

Due to a childhood trauma, you have a fear of prime numbers, consequently

None of the six numbers is prime.
None of the digits in the six numbers is prime.
None of the differences between any two of the six numbers is prime.
The number 1, of course, is not prime.

What six numbers do you play?

Here’s my answer:

[size=1pt]1, 9, 10, 34, 49[/size]

Meets the following conditions:

  1. all are between 1 and 49
  2. difference between each is not the same as any other difference
  3. none of the differences are prime
  4. none of them are prime
  5. none of them contain prime numbers

Edit: Ah, I did get it. For some reason, I kept thinking a difference of 33 was a prime number. Oh well. Not that hard.
[/quote]

Hmm, I got:
4, 10, 16, 40, 44, and 48.

I may have made a mistake, check it please! :)[/quote]

Yeah, what david said. Yours doesn’t follow the principle that the differences between each number is also different from all other differences.

Read full topic

item.title: Riddles/Conundrums?
item.dc:creator: @Team_Rocket Team_Rocket
item.description:

[quote=“chillwitm888, post:14, topic:428706”][quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=531397.msg3883082#msg3883082 date=1326214932]
What goes in hard, but comes out soft and sticky?
[/quote]
gum… not penis[/quote]

I’m surprised someone got it lol.

Read full topic

Every week you play the lottery and you always play the same number. To play you pick six integers between 1 and 49, inclusive.

The numbers you pick have these properties:

The difference between any two of the six numbers is different from the difference between any other pair.

Due to a childhood trauma, you have a fear of prime numbers, consequently

None of the six numbers is prime.
None of the digits in the six numbers is prime.
None of the differences between any two of the six numbers is prime.
The number 1, of course, is not prime.

What six numbers do you play?
[/quote]

Here’s my answer:

[size=1pt]1, 9, 10, 34, 49[/size]

Meets the following conditions:

  1. all are between 1 and 49
  2. difference between each is not the same as any other difference
  3. none of the differences are prime
  4. none of them are prime
  5. none of them contain prime numbers

Edit: Ah, I did get it. For some reason, I kept thinking a difference of 33 was a prime number. Oh well. Not that hard. :P[/quote]

4, 10, 16, 40, 44, and 48.

I may have made a mistake, check it please!

item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Stupit, post:4, topic:428706”]I posted this in the other thread for you, but I’ll post it here also:
Every week you play the lottery and you always play the same number. To play you pick six integers between 1 and 49, inclusive.

The numbers you pick have these properties:

The difference between any two of the six numbers is different from the difference between any other pair.

Due to a childhood trauma, you have a fear of prime numbers, consequently

None of the six numbers is prime.
None of the digits in the six numbers is prime.
None of the differences between any two of the six numbers is prime.
The number 1, of course, is not prime.

What six numbers do you play?[/quote]

Here’s my answer:

[size=1pt]1, 9, 10, 34, 49[/size]

Meets the following conditions:

  1. all are between 1 and 49
  2. difference between each is not the same as any other difference
  3. none of the differences are prime
  4. none of them are prime
  5. none of them contain prime numbers

Edit: Ah, I did get it. For some reason, I kept thinking a difference of 33 was a prime number. Oh well. Not that hard.
